awd_titl_txt: OPUS CRS: Integrating Forty Years of Parasitism Research
awd_abstract_narration:
Parasitism is pervasive and parasites come in all shapes and forms, from viruses, and bacteria to fungi, nematode worms, parasitic plants, and invertebrates such as fleas, mites, lice, bedbugs, and little “parasitoid” insects who lay their eggs on other insects. In fact, nearly every species on our planet has associated parasites that shape their biology. Even parasites have parasites. If we look on even smaller microscopic scales, DNA parasites are found in the genetic material of nearly every organism. How do species survive this onslaught of parasitism, and how do hosts respond to keep them in check? A major focus of this project is to investigate parasitism across different biological levels, and to identify common principles among the very diverse kinds of parasitic relationships. This research is relevant to improving agriculture and advancing human health. The second major goal of this project concerns a specific kind of parasite called “parasitoids”.  Parasitoids are small insects that lay their eggs in other invertebrates, and the resulting young then feed on and kill the “host”.  Parasitoids are among the most abundant of all insects, and they play a major role in controlling insect numbers in nature, including pests and disease vectors. The parasitoid group called Nasonia (jewel wasps) is a highly tractable study group for research and teaching. It has emerged as an insect model for both parasitoid biology and basic research. Yet, a synthetic treatment of Nasonia, including major advances and uses of the system, has not been done in over fifty years.  To fill this gap, and to make the system more available to researchers and educators, a synthetic review of Nasonia will be conducted.  This will include methods, research advances, and information on on-line tools for research and education.  The review will both advance research on parasitoids, and increase public awareness and knowledge about this very important but under-recognized group of insects. 

This research will identify common principles among the very diverse kinds of parasitic relationships to achieve a synthetic analysis, spanning parasitism from genomic parasites to ecological communities. Important themes to be illustrated in the monograph include biological levels of selection, the parasitism-mutualism continuum, genetic conflict, evolved dependencies, antagonistic coevolution versus unidirectional adaptation, coinheritance and fidelity of association, host defenses, and cooption of parasites by hosts. A synthetic monograph will be produced on the insect parasitoid Nasonia, and its uses in research and teaching. This work builds on the principle investigator’s 40 years of experience on these and other parasitoids, during which Nasonia has emerged as an insect model system. The monograph will feature the biology of Nasonia and related insects, genetic, genomic, and other resources, methods, and significant contributions of Nasonia to science, including in behavior, genetics, comparative biology, development, and symbiosis. Nasonia is also an excellent system for teaching at the high school and college levels. The monograph will feature its uses and advantages in teaching, tools, and examples of exercises. Online resources will be updated to assist researchers and teachers in utilizing Nasonia.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Parasites are pervasive and range from genetic parasites within the DNA, to microbes and multicellular parasites. They are associated with nearly all animals and plants, and play an important role in shaping life on our planet. Reported here is work by the principal investigator on parasitism, ranging from parasitoid insects to microbes and parasitic DNA. As adults, parasitoid insects are free-living, but they lay their eggs in other insects, where the young develop into adults, in the process killing their host. Over the past 40 years, Jewel Wasps (Nasonia) parasitoids have been a major focus of study by the principal investigator. These fascinating insects have, in turn, revealed a menagerie of other parasites. For example, Wolbachia are intracellular bacteria that can be mutualists or reproductive parasites. In Nasonia, they induce reproductive incompatibilities between closely related species. Stemming from the Nasonia finding, the principal investigator branched out to investigating their wider distribution, contributing to the discovery that Wolbachia infect upwards of 50% of terrestrial invertebrates. Other parasites under study occur within the DNA of species, such a parasitic chromosome found in Nasonia, and satellite DNA, which is found in and makes up a large portion of the DNAs of nearly all animals and plants. Satellite DNA has been described as “junk” or parasitic, but may have important functions. Regardless, the de novo origin of satellites is not well understood. We show that one source of nuclear satellites is the cellular organelle mitochondria. When mitochondrial DNA is transferred to the nucleus, the satellites can undergo expansion, providing a previously undescribed source of satellite DNA.

One theme explored in the current proposal is the basis of host shifts by parasites.  Humanity is now experiencing such a host shift, the SARS-CoV-2 virus that causes Covid-19, from its (likely) original bat host into our species, with devastating consequences. By examining over 600 Wolbachia strains, we have found many examples of major host shifts in insects and other invertebrates. These highly replicated “natural experiments” can lead to future studies of how these bacteria move between host species, how they adapt to the new environment, and their consequences to the new host. Whole DNA sequencing of a related species to Nasonia revealed an associated fungal parasite call Nosema, and further work shows that different Nosema types jump between distantly related insects, where they can cause disease. Jewel Wasps have generalist species, that can parasitize a variety of hosts, and specialist that utilize only one type. In a set of genetic experiments, a gene involved in this host choice “decision” has been narrowed to a small region of DNA. Once the gene is identified, the findings could be relevant to use of parasitoids in “pest control”, as well as general questions about how parasites shift hosts at the genetic level. Nasonia is the genetic model for parasitoids.  A review of the genetics of Nasonia and its relatives may also prove a useful source of information on advancing these insects in biological pest control.  Another important aspect has been preservation and dissemination of Jewel Wasp strains, field collected materials, and unpublished results to the research community, to maintain and promote this emerging model system.  

Finally, proteins are the major building blocks for cells and organisms, and networks of proteins play important roles cellular functions, including defense against parasites. We have employed an approach to study protein interactions called evolutionary rate correlation. The idea is that proteins that functionally interact are more likely to show correlated rates of evolution (i.e. they coevolve). This can be used as a “prescreening tool” to identify candidates for protein interactions for further study. In earlier NSF funded research, we used this approach to investigate the “evolutionary partners” of ACE2, the cell receptor that the SARS-CoV-2 binds to enter cells. This revealed interesting candidates involved in immunity that may be relevant to covid-19 disease.  We have now greatly expanded the data set to 15,000 proteins in mammals.  These data both confirm known and predict new protein interactions involved in immunity and other cellular processes. Taken together, the work reported here, from DNA parasites to parasitoids and protein networks, explores parasites and their consequences across a broad range of biological systems.
